Award.AwardTitle: Signaling Mechanisms in the Crustacean Molting Gland
Award.AbstractNarration: Growth in crustaceans requires the periodic shedding of the shell, a process called molting, which is controlled by an endocrine center in the eyestalks. The center secretes two peptide hormones, molt-inhibiting hormone (MIH) and crustacean hyperglycemic hormone (CHH), which inhibit a pair of molting glands (Y-organs or YOs) located in the body. It is the YO, when activated by a drop in MIH, that makes the hormone (ecdysteroid) required for molting. Coordination of molting processes involves a complex interaction between the YO and the eyestalk endocrine center that is poorly understood. It is thought that binding of MIH and CHH to membrane receptors activates separate signaling pathways that converge at cyclic nucleotide-dependent inhibition of enzymes that make ecdysteroid. The YO is a dynamic tissue responsive to changing hormonal conditions. Thus, it is the integration of the hormonal signals by the YO that ultimately determines when an animal molts. Using a comparative approach that incorporates a variety of biochemical and molecular techniques, the project will determine the components of the MIH and CHH signaling pathways and how molting and limb regeneration affect YO sensitivity to MIH and CHH. Understanding the hormonal regulation of crustacean molting and growth is essential to manage fisheries, develop effective aquaculture practices, and mitigate potential effects of pollutants, such as endocrine disruptors. Despite intense effort, very little is known about the molting gland responds to varying hormonal stimuli. Now that methods to express large amounts of active MIH and CHH are available, the signaling pathways can be elucidated and potential interactions with other hormones and pollutants can be determined. The potential role of nitric oxide in MIH signaling constitutes an entirely novel and exciting line of investigation. The project will train a postdoctoral fellow, two graduate students, and four undergraduates in advanced molecular biological techniques.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit. Shrimps, crabs, and lobsters have a hard shell that provides mechanical protection and support. However, the shell restricts growth and therefore it must periodically be shed through a process termed molting. Molting is a complex process that requires the precise coordination of physiological processes and environmental cues by hormones. It is controlled by two endocrine organs: the X-organ/sinus gland (XO/SG) complex in the eyestalks and the molting glands or Y-organs (YO) in the body. The YO makes steroid molting hormones that initiate the synthesis of a new shell under the old shell as the animal prepares to molt. The XO/SG produces a neuropeptide, molt-inhibiting hormone (MIH), that inhibits the YO and therefore keeps the animal from molting. The major goal of the project was to understand how MIH inhibits the YO, and in particular identifying genes in the MIH signaling pathway. We developed a unified model involving nitric oxide and cyclic nucleotides as second messengers, which provided a framework for the study of signaling genes. We discovered two highly conserved pathways that control growth and differentiation in other organisms, mTOR and TGFbeta, are involved. mTOR is important for the activation of the YO and TGFbeta is important for the commitment of the animal to molt. The integration of these signaling pathways is critical for understanding how environmental stresses affect growth in this economically and ecologically important group of marine animals.

Broader impacts. The project has provided training in biochemical and molecular biological techniques to 3 graduate and 7 undergraduate students. It provided experience in mentoring students by the postdoctoral fellows and graduate students. The postdoctoral fellows are now establishing labs of their own at UNC-Wilmington (Joe Covi) and at Linfield College (Kyle MacLea). The project resulted in 12 peer-reviewed publications and 17 meeting abstracts.
